question: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of colicky abdominal pain and diarrhea. He has bowel movements 10–12 times daily; the stool contains blood and mucus. He constantly has the urge to defecate. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the abdomen shows diffuse tenderness to palpation. Serum concentration of C-reactive protein is 20 mg/L (N<10). Colonoscopy shows a bleeding, ulcerated rectal mucosa with several pseudopolyps. Which of the following is this patient at greatest risk of developing?
predict: {"step_by_step_thinking": "To approach this question, we need to analyze the patient's symptoms and test results to identify the underlying condition. The patient presents with colicky abdominal pain, diarrhea, frequent bowel movements (10-12 times daily), and the presence of blood and mucus in the stool. These symptoms are suggestive of an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). The patient's elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) level further supports the presence of inflammation. Colonoscopy reveals a bleeding, ulcerated rectal mucosa with several pseudopolyps, which is a hallmark of ulcerative colitis (UC), a type of IBD. Given that the patient has a history of ulcerative colitis, we need to consider complications associated with this condition.", "answer_choice": "C"}
